Award.AwardTitle: Workshop Proposal: Russian Elite Attitudes Toward Conflict and the West

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
GENERAL ABSTRACT

Over the past two years, the relationship between Russia and the U.S. has undergone a seismic shift. US-Russian relations are now more confrontational than at any point since the Mikhail Gorbachev era began in 1985. This project convenes two workshops to analyze the sources of this conflict, bringing together leading scholars from the U.S., Europe, and Russia. Scholars will analyze and present papers based on a series of more than 1600 interviews with high-ranking individuals working in Russia's federal bureaucracy, parliament, military and security agencies, private businesses, state-owned enterprises, universities and academic research institutes, and major media outlets that spans a period from 1993 to 2016. These papers will be published as a co-edited volume that should be of interest to policy experts and academics alike. By exploring the foreign policy attitudes of a broad swath of Russian elites, the project should promote a deeper understanding of the causes of -- and possible ways to moderate -- Russia's recent belligerence in the post-Soviet region and its confrontational stance toward the West.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT

We plan to convene two workshops to analyze the sources of the resurgent conflict between Russia and the U.S. that has accompanied President Vladimir Putin's return to the presidency in 2012. Leading scholars from the U.S., Europe, and Russia will analyze and present papers based on a unique data source -- a series of interviews of high-ranking individuals working in Russia's federal bureaucracy, parliament, military and security agencies, private businesses, state-owned enterprises, universities and academic research institutes, and major media outlets. The series, conducted on a quadrennial basis since 1993 and extending to 2016, consists of seven waves. It includes 1,664 surveys that feature a consistent survey methodology, the use of the same Moscow-based polling firm, and the replication of most survey questions. These are the only repeated cross-sectional survey data of Russian elites extant anywhere and as such, constitute a unique resource for the scholarly community. The papers written using the data will be published as a co-edited volume that should be of interest to policy experts and academics alike. By exploring the foreign policy attitudes of a broad swath of Russian elites, the project should promote a deeper understanding of the causes of -- and possible ways to moderate -- Russia's recent belligerence in the post-Soviet region and its confrontational stance toward the West.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was organized around the Survey of Russian Elites (SRE)--a series of surveys of high-ranking Russians working in occupations related to foreign affairs that have been conducted roughly every four years since 1993. Although the SRE is not a panel study that re-interviews the same individuals over time, it is unique in that it is the only repeated cross-sectional survey of contemporary Russian foreign policy elites available. Moreover, since the survey has asked many of the same questions repeatedly over more than two decades, the data set (containing responses from 1,909 individuals) provides a window into how attitudes as a whole have changed over time.

 

This NSF award made it possible to convene two workshops designed to improve our understanding of the foreign and domestic policy views of influential Russians. At the first, held at Hamilton College in April 2018, twenty participants presented and evaluated original research based on the SRE. Many of the papers were subsequently published in a special double issue of Post-Soviet Affairs that addressed four questions: 1) How impactful are "cues" emanating from the Kremlin and conveyed through the media on elites' attitudes about foreign policy?, 2) How does conceptualizing Russia as part of "Western civilization" shape one's expectations of leadership turnover?, 3) How ideologically coherent are the foreign and domestic policy positions of high-ranking Russians?, and 4) Do subdivisions within the elite (e.g., between more influential groups and less influential groups) determine foreign policy attitudes?

 

The second workshop was held at the Annual Convention of the Association for Slavic, East European, and Eurasian Studies in December 2018. It served as the founding meeting of the SRE's International Advisory Board, which is comprised of fifteen members from four countries. Among other issues, the workshop participants discussed ways to launch the 2020 wave of the SRE in such a way as to increase its use, academic and policy relevance, and impact.

 

The award also made it possible to field an eighth wave of the SRE in February-March 2020. The 2020 survey measured the views of high-ranking Russians on policy-relevant issues, such as Russia's relations with Ukraine, China, the EU, and the US; perceived threats to Russian security, including NATO expansion and cyberattacks; the deployment of troops abroad; and the justifiability of political protests.

 

Overall, the investigators and their team produced ten journal articles, two contributions to The Washington Post's widely read blog, The Monkey Cage, and a 52-page, single-spaced policy report. An additional panel presentation based on the data is scheduled for the Annual Convention of the Association for Slavic, East European, and Eurasian Studies in November 2020.

 

Intellectually, the project demonstrates how survey data on Russian elites can answer broader questions in established subfields of political science, such as political psychology, public opinion, and the comparative study of authoritarianism. The publications produced with this award also highlight the relevance of "cueing"--a process by which highly placed Russians carefully read Kremlin signals and adopt policies that mirror those of the top leadership. Several journal articles in the special issue show when and how this occurs, and the policy report based on the 2020 data illuminate some important differences between foreign and domestic policy. On specific international issues such as Russia's involvement with Syria and China, for instance, there are signs of receptivity to "cueing." In some domestic areas, however, elites are not as receptive to the Kremlin's cues as one might expect. Specifically, our respondents' views on the threat of a "color" revolution in Russia, the need for strong Internet regulation, and whether or not the U.S. interfered in Russia's 2011-12 election cycle diverge noticeably from President Vladimir Putin's statements.

 

In terms of the broader social impact, the investigators provided opportunities for training and professional development in this project. The workshops, as well as the new International Advisory Board of the SRE, involved leading U.S, European, and Russian scholars and policy experts in different career tracks and at different levels, including junior and senior faculty members and graduate students. The investigators also solicited suggestions for the inclusion of specific survey questions on the 2020 survey from interested scholars employed at a wide array of institutions, and those questions will be used in ongoing research projects. In addition, the award enabled the investigators to offer a supervised research training opportunity in survey research methods and analysis to eleven undergraduate students at two institutions--both in an upper-level survey research course taught in the spring of 2020 and in a faculty-led research group directed in the summer of 2020.

 

In addition to the two posts in The Washington Post, the findings of the 2020 survey were disseminated via a webcast by Hamilton College and were subsequently featured on a listserv that is used extensively by scholars and policy experts in the Russian studies field.
